div1.p: LePrince and Carter offer suggestions for the control of malaria on the plantations of the United Fruit Company.

div1.head: Report: Suggestions for the Control of Malaria on the Plantations of the United Fruit Company, by Joseph A. LePrince and Henry Rose Carter, September 7, 1928
div1.opener:
/LC
PLEASE RETURN TO FILE.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Septem 7/28
Suggestions for the Control of Malaria
on the Plantations
of the United Fruit Company:
Agreed on by
J. A. LePrince and H. R. Carter.
div1.p:
It is understood that the malaria here considered is that oc-
curring among the colored and native laborers, employees of the
Fruit Company, living in quarters controlled by the Company, and the
following methods are suggested as being at the same time practicable
and as capable of giving a reasonable amont of control of the malaria
among them:
I: As much prevention of Anopheles production as is economically
possible.
II: The use of repellants about the quarters of employees.
III: Daily hand-killing of Anopheles in quarters.
IV: Attempting the cure (i. e. freeing from infection) of em-
ployees treated for malarial fever.
I: Prevention of Anopheles Production.

Since cost has to be considered as well as health, it is imprac-
ticable to carry this method out fully, as was done on the Canal Zone
for example. We must therefore select such breeding places the cost
of control of which is justified by the prevention of the injury from
the malaria they would have produced.

The advisability of the control of any particular breeding place
then should depend on (1) the cost of its control and (2) the amount
of malaria it, uncontrolled, will produce.

The Cost of Control depends on the nature of the breeding place:
the surrounding topography: cost of labor and other factors determina-
ble only by the man on the ground. The cost of up-keep must be con-
sidered in the cost.
cost.

The Amount of Malaria caused by a breeding place depends mainly on
the following factors:
(a) Species of Anopheles produced:
(b) Number of Anopheles produced.
(c) Proximity of breeding place to quarters.

(a) Species of Anopheles. Naturally a place produc-
ing species that are efficient vectors of malaria causes more malaria
than one producing the same number of a less efficient vector.

On the Canal Zone, A. albimanus and A. tarsimaculata
(both are Cellia in Theobald's classification) were certainly our
principal (possibly almost our only) vectors of malaria. They were
very abundant: easier to infect than the other species: much more gen-
erally found in houses and capable of long flights.

I If the species of Anopheles on the plantations on the
plantations be the same and present the same biology as on the Canal
Zone and if we have to differentiate between the control of the pro-
duction of the different species it would be advisable to give prece-
dence to control of places producing these two species --i. e. to con-
centrate on them. Research on this matter on the plantations seems ad-
visable as all of them may not show the same Anopheles, or their Ano-
pheles may not show the same characterists as on the Canal Zone.

(b) The number of Anopheles produced. This needs no
discussion.

(c) Proximity to quarters. Nor does this need dis-
cussion, although we cannot assert that the amount of malaria produced
at any place is always proportional (inversely) to its distance from
the breeding place causing it. (Foot note)

(Foot note): Proximity of the breeding place to quarters is, of course,
, of course,
-3-
only one factor in the accessibility of the men we wish to protect to
the Anopheles produced from this breeding place. With this might be
included a number of others: as intervening woods: hills: collections
of residenced: the direction, time of day and strength of winds: whether
the quarters are screened etc. All of these things may be considered
by the man on the ground, but the data on most of them are decidedly
unsatisfactory and certainly to discuss them would make this Memorandum,
intended to be simple, unduly complicated. (End of Foot note).
II: The Use of Repellants about the Quarters.

This method is suggested tentatively only. It is cheap and the
results reported by Coogle in the Mississippi Delta were good. It is
suggested that Dr. Deeks get in touch with Dr. Fricks at Memphis (or
with the Bureau of the U. S. Public Health Service, Washington, D. C.)
to obtain the results of this method to date, including those of 1924.
III: The Daily Hand-killing of Anopheles in Quarters.

This gave good results on the Canal Zone and at the Resevoir at
Camp Eustis, Va. Men skilled in finding the Anopheles would be ne-
cessary in the beginning. Whether the people living in the house,
after being taught to find the insects, could be trusted to keep the
house free of them is a question. It would be a great advantage if they
could, but even if this has to be done in perpetuity by men paid by the
Company it still ranks as a method cheap in proportion to its efficacy.

IV: Attempt to Cure (Free from Infection) Patients Treated for
Malaria.

This will quite frequently be impossible, the patient refusing, or
failing, to continue proper treatment long enough. Yet, with the greater
resistance of negroes to malaria, cure possibly would be less infrequent
than our observations on white men have led us to expect. Here too is need
for research and in a virgin field.
field.

The regular administration of quinine to well people to immunize
them against the bites of infective Anopheles is not recommended except
in a temporary emergency when the exposure to a malignant malaria is
very great, as in gangs opening up new lands: the occurrence of an unu-
sually severe and general epidemic of malaria etc.
